text:
Curious, how are others calculating ROI/ROT, particularly for LAY bets? I do the following but not sure if it's the best way to get a ballpark figure for strategy comparison...
`back_roi = sum(profit) / sum(matched_stakes)
lay_roi = sum(profit) / sum(liabilities)`

I treat every bet as an individual but there's also an argument for calculating at market level which is more complicated. There's also an argument for calculating lay bets using the matched stakes only which gives like for like comparison between back and lay bets, however that doesn't fully reflect the liability/risk?

elements.text: Curious, how are others calculating ROI/ROT, particularly for LAY bets? I do the following but not sure if it's the best way to get a ballpark figure for strategy comparison...
back_roi = sum(profit) / sum(matched_stakes)
lay_roi = sum(profit) / sum(liabilities)

I treat every bet as an individual but there's also an argument for calculating at market level which is more complicated. There's also an argument for calculating lay bets using the matched stakes only which gives like for like comparison between back and lay bets, however that doesn't fully reflect the liability/risk?

text: There is no right way to compute it. What are you really trying to accomplish when you compare ROI across strategies? The return on capital of sports betting strategies is usually very large, making capital/investment not a meaningful input

elements.text: There is no right way to compute it. What are you really trying to accomplish when you compare ROI across strategies? The return on capital of sports betting strategies is usually very large, making capital/investment not a meaningful input

text:
```roi = sum(profit) / sum(matched_stakes)```
Everything else is wrong

elements.text: roi = sum(profit) / sum(matched_stakes)
Everything else is wrong

text:
I suppose I'm just trying to get a number to use for comparing strategy A vs B and thinking about it like an interest rate or investment return. I've also seen people use their bankroll growth to calculate, i.e. deposit £500, bankroll now = £750 = 250 / 500 = 50%. 

<@U4H19D1D2> I am inclined to agree but laying £1 @ 100 is £99 risk rather than £1, so what are your thoughts/findings on just using matched sizes?

elements.text: I suppose I'm just trying to get a number to use for comparing strategy A vs B and thinking about it like an interest rate or investment return. I've also seen people use their bankroll growth to calculate, i.e. deposit £500, bankroll now = £750 = 250 / 500 = 50%.
I am inclined to agree but laying £1 @ 100 is £99 risk rather than £1, so what are your thoughts/findings on just using matched sizes?

text: But it evens out, you can say the same about backing £1 @ 100, liabilities is meaningless

elements.text: But it evens out, you can say the same about backing £1 @ 100, liabilities is meaningless

text: Sports betting returns are typically 100%+ annual ROI on account capital, making interest rates and ROI calculations pretty meaningless at that point. It's just not an important metric

elements.text: Sports betting returns are typically 100%+ annual ROI on account capital, making interest rates and ROI calculations pretty meaningless at that point. It's just not an important metric

text: In my apparently wrong opinion it should be `sum(profit) / sum(liability)` where for back bets the liability is equal to the matched stake. I also use ROI as the headline metric in comparing strategies, monitoring for degrading strategy performance, identifying areas where strategies need improvement, and evaluating the impact of said improvements

elements.text: In my apparently wrong opinion it should be
sum(profit) / sum(liability)

where for back bets the liability is equal to the matched stake. I also use ROI as the headline metric in comparing strategies, monitoring for degrading strategy performance, identifying areas where strategies need improvement, and evaluating the impact of said improvements

text: <@UBS7QANF3> Why not just use profit instead of ROI for that purpose?

elements.text: Why not just use profit instead of ROI for that purpose?

text: Obvious reasons? If strategy A is risking 10 times the amount per bet to strategy B then you need some kind of standardisation. If strategy C has the same profit as strategy D but C had to risk a lot to get there then it might not be worth tying up capital on strategy C, or you might infer that strategy C is much closer to liquidity limits

elements.text: Obvious reasons? If strategy A is risking 10 times the amount per bet to strategy B then you need some kind of standardisation. If strategy C has the same profit as strategy D but C had to risk a lot to get there then it might not be worth tying up capital on strategy C, or you might infer that strategy C is much closer to liquidity limits

text: (one vote for the Liam method) but it doesn't matter how you calculate it because it's a number only you use rather than comparing with others. But it's the bottom line that matters, 0.2% of £1m turnover is obv better than 1% on £100k. RoI in financials is a useful comparison because the investment is effectively unlimited. In sports its turnover that's going to be the real issue.

elements.text: (one vote for the Liam method) but it doesn't matter how you calculate it because it's a number only you use rather than comparing with others. text: <@UBS7QANF3> variance in returns or some similar metric solves the first problem way better. ROI (calculated as discussed) is a poor proxy for figuring out how much capital a strategy is tying up. Best to track that directly

elements.text: variance in returns or some similar metric solves the first problem way better. ROI (calculated as discussed) is a poor proxy for figuring out how much capital a strategy is tying up. Best to track that directly

text: ```roi = market_net_profit / market_peak_expo```

text: I don't see how measuring exposure relates to 'return on investment', in my eyes its a valuable tool in comparing strategies across backing/laying alongside profit, as soon as you add in exposure it isn't

elements.text: I don't see how measuring exposure relates to 'return on investment', in my eyes its a valuable tool in comparing strategies across backing/laying alongside profit, as soon as you add in exposure it isn't

text: well the amount you invest in a market is your exposure by definition, you have lost the utility of this amount of money, and roi is the ratio of net profit to investment.

elements.text: well the amount you invest in a market is your exposure by definition, you have lost the utility of this amount of money, and roi is the ratio of net profit to investment.

text: <@U05L8PZD2FM> but you can turnover thousands on a market and never have an exposure greater than 100.

text: imagine you have £1, you compare two investments based on ROI to determine which you should buy. It is only useful if you are capital constrained.

elements.text: imagine you have £1, you compare two investments based on ROI to determine which you should buy. It is only useful if you are capital constrained.

text: if you had £2 and were only allowed to put £1 in each you would buy both irrespective of their ROI

text: Exactly, RoI isn't significant if you have sufficient capital to exploit the exposure limits. Which we do. I don't care if I make 1% or 10% because the issue is what's it a percentage of.

```sum(net_profit)/sum(matched_payout)```

text:
Oh no, what have I started? :man-facepalming: :grinning: 
Looks like <@UBS7QANF3> does it the same way that I do, although <@U05L8PZD2FM>'s method also seems sensible. My thinking was to treat it like a financial investment where I've risked X and have return Y, therefore return is `profit / risk`. Ultimately bankroll growth is the bottom line.
